distributedcloud/dcmanager/api/controlle.message: Isn't it cleaner to send an rpc to the subcloud_audit_manager? This is going to be a rare event so we don't care about the cost (which is minimal anyways).
I'd rather not set the precedent of manipulating the database here if it isn't required so I prefer that you convert this to a RPC.

It buys us encapsulation. The API code doesn't currently access the audit DB tables from what I can see and it shouldn't. We should be able to extend/modify these tables and only impact the audit code (not the API code). We should be able to add logic to the RPC handling code in the audit and be confident that it will apply to all the users (including the API).

In this particular case we're only specifying the fact that we want to trigger a load audit.  We could add a new audit type and modify the helper function and this code would still be valid and would not need to be restarted.  I don't see how changing this to use an RPC call would improve encapsulation for *this* use-case.

(Now if we wanted to trigger *all* subcloud audits like trigger_subcloud_audits() does, then you'd have a point since all users of the API would need to be restarted to pick up the new code if we add a new audit type.  So maybe we shouldn't get rid of the  existing trigger_subcloud_audits() RPC call.)

We already access the DB from the api code, so that's nothing new.  As long as we don't need serialization (and we don't) I think it's cleaner to just call a helper function to do the DB operation directly than to send an RPC to another entity to run the same code on our behalf.

And I'm half tempted to get rid of the existing trigger_subcloud_audits() RPC call that we recently added in favour of just calling a helper function to do the DB update since the RPC doesn't actually buy us anything.
OK. I checked and this is fine.  "return" is the same as "return None", which both tell pecan to use http code 204 (no content)

I guess we could test both, but I bet there are other tests that update changes after events.  The one new one we need is a test that doesn't emit an event.
Should we not emit the event so that we better test the "refresh" functionality?

Based on clarification on irc: Initially (when the parent change didn't exist yet). An event was neccesary to trigger an update of the data which is used by canMerge. With the parent change canMerge on Github updates this information on the fly for the cycle-can-merge check due to lack of events we can receive from github (notably branch protection changes).

Now that we use the allow_refresh in this change we can omit the event in this test case to test both, the parent change and this change at once.
This test was intended to model a work flow where we don't get any event (e.g. github branch protection). Maybe we want to test both cases.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
What events don't trigger updates of cached changes?  Why shouldn't we add handling for those events?

This method gets called a lot, and refreshing is expensive.  We really should try to avoid doing this.

It sort of looks like you may have been going for an idea where the current (non-refresh) behavior is used in all of the current call locations, but the new refresh behavior is used in the next change?

If that's the case, it's probably worth mentioning in the commit message.  That way reviewers fully understand the purpose of the change.  It's probably not apparent when you read this, but every paragraph of this comment was written after leaving this change and going somewhere else to try to understand it.

Further, if that is the case, then I think that helps address my concern in the first paragraph.  I'm going to assume so and review the rest of the change under those assumptions.  But I'd still like to know what sort of events we're missing.

The main reason for this was that there was an earlier optimization to store all information that's needed for a canmerge check within the change for github prs (https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/753243). Before that optimization we did refreshing the canmerge information on every call. Due to github's limitations it is not possible to reliably update this information. E.g. this depends on the branch protection settings of github where it doesn't send any event if this changed. Also status events can be ambiguous.

Anyway as you see in the github part we don't refresh the whole change but fetch only the required data. If I recall correctly exactly this was the issue we tried to fix here. However maybe this change goes too far and should only add a 'allow-refresh' flag that triggers refreshing of such volatile information (on github) and remove the refreshing from the other drivers where we don't have this problem.

tldr: I'd suggest to change this flag to 'allow-refresh' and only make the github driver act on this flag (maybe later gitlab needs similar things).

It might be good to standardize -- it helps in reviews like this where we're jumping across all the drivers.  I'd vote for True but would be happy with either.

cinder/volume/drivers/remotefs.py.message:
I don't think we should be adding additional logic here that checks the length of snap_info.

Isn't this a different way to determine the same thing that's determined above at line 1550?
Similar, yes. I moved it up.

AFAIK '_snapshots_exist' hasn't a relationship with the creation/deletion of snapshots.

 I'm following the steps in the launchpad (#1813138) and this method is never called. This method is only used in L1054 when cloning volumes...

I'm using 'openstack volume snapshot delete' to delete the snapshots. I wonder how can I delete snapshots with Nova as you reported?

You're correct. The issue comes up not during snapshot deletion but afterwards. If _create_cloned_volume is called after hitting the issue described in #1813138 it will compare active_fpath and base_vol_path. However as described in the bug the provider_location will point to a wrong (no longer existing) path which will (in this scenario) cause a wrong result for the _snapshots_exist method. This is described in the last paragraph of the bug ticket. The method will report existing snapshots while there are none.

So, yes, this is not related to the snapshot deletion but a bug during snapshot deletion can cause an incorrect path to be used in here.

I added the checks in the _snapshots_exist method in order to detect a no-snapshots-exist state quicker and more reliably.

Does this answer your question?

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Please explain why we need to add 'none' to the config explicitly now. If the none authtype worked before the patch [1] without extra configuration but does not work after it, then I guess this will impact the Wallaby upgrade as well. Does the deployers need to change the configuration during the upgrade to keep the VNC working as before?

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/622336

Yes, this isn't something we should do. From the original spec that introduced this option [1]:

  When enabling vencrypt for an existing deployment, two stages will be required.
  Initially the [vnc]auth_schemes configuration parameter will need to list both
  vencrypt and none auth schemes. This allows the proxy to connect to both
  pre-existing deployed compute hosts which do not have TLS turned on and newly
  updated compute with TLS. Once all compute hosts have been updated to enable
  TLS, the [vnc] auth_schemes configuration parameter can be switched to only
  permit vencrypt.

So if you're having to enable this, that suggests TLS is not properly configured. Setting none merely masks over the issue

[1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/queens/implemented/websocket-proxy-to-host-security.html#other-deployer-impact

manila_tempest_tests/tests/api/admin/tes.message: Formerly you added extra specs onto those already set whereas now you are using only the backend name and DHSS.  Are you sure that we don't need stuff like the snapshot support capabilities here?

Thanks Goutham,
This clean up requires changes in many tests for the reason of using ddt for testing different API versions. 
So let's get this patch merged and the clean up will be done later.

In the existing tests there isn't snapshot creation. So here we don't need this capability.
In case we extend the tests to snapshot creation, I'll make the necessary changes.
But currently there is no need.

One of the objectives that we had when we started creating share types on the fly was this. A test can setup whatever extra specs it needs in the share types it creates.

But we have a bit of an issue here, until API version 2.24, "snapshot_support" *is a required extra-spec* and we added ``create_share_from_snapshot_support`` alongside it, defaulting to the value of "snapshot_support" - but allowing an override. All other capabilities are added when needed. 

I wanted to get this stuff cleaned up. We always seem to create share types with the latest version configured in the config file. API version 2.24 is too old for us to maintain compatibility for. I've no problem ensuring that tempest always tests older microversions, but, we can stop supporting setting "LATEST_MICROVERSION=2.23" (or lesser). That way, we can fix "add_extra_specs_to_dict" to stop adding "snapshot_support" and "create_share_from_snapshot_support" automatically. We can request them in the snapshot and snapshot cloning tests explicitly.

os_brick/initiator/connectors/iscsi.py.message:
Shouldn't this catch a narrower class of exceptions, such as those that we expect self._execute() to raise?

Just catching and ignoring all exceptions seems too broad and may hide things that we should fail on.

Current problem is that os-brick doesn't fail but gets hung if any uncaught exception is raised from _connect_vol when multipath is enabled. We can avoind the hung caused by failure in iscsiadm command by using ProcessExecutionError but we would still hit the similar issue if any other exception is raised. That's why I implemented my patch initially with generic Exception.

Also, failures caused by unhandled exceptions are supposed to be caught be the subsequent logic to check failed_logins or found_devices thus they are not completely ignored.

One difference this change makes is that volume connection with single path is not aborted even when an unhandled exception is raised here, but it is tried with the other connectors (if there are multiple portals given). I think it is reasonable considering the case the error is specific to only some of the portals.
nit: move the `session = None` to L633 and replace the pass there

-1: We also need to add exit code 2 to this list, because that's the error that's reported in the BZ (even if there's no mention to it in the LP bug).

According to the iscsiadm man page:

     2      ISCSI_ERR_SESS_NOT_FOUND - session could not be found.

I've looked at the Open iSCSI code, and it looks like this could happen because of a bug in Open iSCSI.

It's a race condition they don't protect again, so the ideal here would be to have a couple of retries if the exit code is 2.

In any case, that improvement doesn't invalidate this patch, and getting this patch in this release is definitely important, so let's leave the improvement for another patch.
Sorry, what race condition? It is the first time I read about it.

> -1: We also need to add exit code 2 to this list, because that's the error that's reported in the BZ (even if there's no mention to it in the LP bug).

Yes. This issue was discovered in downstream bz1923975(mentioned in the LP bug) and triggered by exit code 2 from iscsi -m session (I didn't mention this in bz or LP bug. I'll put this later).

I hesitate to add 2 because IIUC it is not an expected return code. In the real situation, 2 was returned because of wrong reference in the iscsiadm command triggered by race condition, so adding 2 into check_exit_code makes that wrong behavior of the iscsiadm command ignored.

If we agree to ignore 2 assuming that the return code 2 would indicate a bug of iscsiadm command caused by race condition with iscsiadm command, then it's ok.

Same comment as with a previous change RE: suffixing these to make it obvious that they're new entirely instances
Yeah, I tried to add unshelve tests for image-based instances in the past. This is an ugly issue to fix

As far as I see why it fails is due to the ImageBackendFixture that mock disks and when the libvirt driver takes a snapshot of a disk for shelving an instance there will be a 'location': <MagicMock name='mock.direct_snapshot()' key added to the resulting image metadata dict. It is stored by the glance fixture. When the glance fixture try to return that metadata during unshelve it tries  to copy the stored dict, but MagicMock cannot be deep copied.

Direct snapshot does not need to be implemented by the mocked disk as it is mostly not implemented in the real image backends. So I made it raise NotImplementedError from ImageBackendFixture. This makes the unshelve succeed here.

I've pushed a patch top of this to fix the fixture and re-enable this step of the test case. https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/778462

neutron/api/rpc/handlers/dhcp_rpc.py.message: Please clarify why changing behavior here, why need to deal with DHCP agents if dhcp scheduler extension is disabled?

Why not just check "enable_distributed_dhcp" option and return empty list if it's True?
Or is it a side change not related to distributed DHCP?

Ok so now we'll return active networks only in case there is an active DHCP agent (host arg becomes required), even if DHCP scheduling extension is disabled. Changed behavior should ot be a big issue as the method is private.

I've considered about add the config option check condition. But here is a bit common for DHCP agent, no matter the new mechanism status.

If DHCP agent is admin state down , it should not sync any networks anymore. If the neutron DB has no such DHCP agent, it should not sync any networks data to it as well.

Only the alive and existing DHCP agent should sync all active networks.

This is the scenario I've left before 😊
"""
If DHCP agent is admin state down , it should not sync any networks anymore. If the neutron DB has no such DHCP agent, it should not sync any networks data to it as well.
"""
So I will repeat:

The running DHCP agent has no consciousness of "admin state", it is a DB state only. So everytime, a DHCP agent (with admin state DOWN state) is trying to do some sync action, these code here will return all networks to it. This is not right for a "DOWN" agent. Actually, it should sync nothing.

For a none-exist DHCP agent, the python DHCP agent is running but no Agent in neutron DB, neutron server should return empty list as well.

The following is the basic call stack:

sync_state
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/agent/dhcp/agent.py#L137
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/agent/dhcp/agent.py#L345
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/agent/dhcp/agent.py#L253

RPC: get_active_networks_info
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/agent/dhcp/agent.py#L840-L845
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/api/rpc/handlers/dhcp_rpc.py#L139-L143

This function： _get_active_networks
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/api/rpc/handlers/dhcp_rpc.py#L80-L93
Please describe the scenario this change is fixing. If agent is dead or admin state down then who could be requesting networks info?

/COMMIT_MSG.message: do we know why the user creation is making the home dir have different owner/group?

Not really, and that's the reason why I needed the extra task.
The interesting thing is the following:

"""
- hosts: overcloud
  become: true
  tasks:
    - name: create user
      user:
        name: test


[root@standalone ~]# ls -ldZ /home/*
drwx------.  2 qemu    qemu    unconfined_u:object_r:user_home_dir_t:s0   62 Mar  3 10:44 /home/qemu
drwx------.  2    1001    1002 unconfined_u:object_r:user_home_dir_t:s0   62 Mar  3 13:16 /home/test
[root@standalone ~]# getent group | grep test
test:x:1003:
[root@standalone ~]# getent passwd | grep test
test:x:1002:1003::/home/test:/bin/bash
[root@standalone ~]#
"""

But .... running the same playbook with: hosts: localhost OR hosts: overcloud the home directory is created w/o issues.

"""

- hosts: overcloud
  become: true
  tasks:
    - name: create user
      user:
         name: test1
[root@standalone ~]# ls -ldZ /home/*
drwx------.  2 qemu    qemu    unconfined_u:object_r:user_home_dir_t:s0   62 Mar  3 10:44 /home/qemu
drwx------.  2    1001    1002 unconfined_u:object_r:user_home_dir_t:s0   62 Mar  3 13:16 /home/test
drwx------.  2    test1    test1 unconfined_u:object_r:user_home_dir_t:s0   62 Mar  3 13:18 /home/test1


So it's clearly related to the useradd module run against the inventory provided. There are no other passes on the directory where permissions are changed

This ends up with a suuuper wide table. I would tend to think that in the default case, a shell user really just wants to see if their import is done (or progressing). They initiated the request, so they don't really need to know all the details. They want to see the message and status. I really think the non-verbose case can just be that. They called this with the image-id, so showing that in the table is redundant and just takes up space. Also, a shell user probably doesn't need to know that they (user_id) submitted the request, and they probably can't use the task_id for anything unless they are an admin. The request_id is mostly only useful for a script or other service that is trying to follow a request.

All that to say... how about in the default case we just show "message" and "status"? And actually, how about adding updated_at into the default list? I think the user will be running this default case with the question of "what is the status of my import?" and updated_at,message,status is the meat of that answer.

For --verbose, adding all the other stuff makes sense.

Is it misleading as we are supporting it for v2.12?

Server does not support image tasks API below (v2.12)

The way this reads is "The server does not support 2.12, which is required for the thing you ask me to do". So, I think it makes sense to me as a native speaker.

We could change the wording maybe, if you think it would be more clear:

"Server does not support API v2.12 which is required when querying for image tasks"

Is that better?
Makes more sense after your explanation, no need to change.

manifests/backend/dellemc_xtremio.pp.message:
If this expects comma-separated list then how about implementing something like

 join(any2array($xtremio_ports), ',')

This allows us to use list in addition to a single string and would be helpful when a user wants to put multiple items.
I wanted this to look similar to other Dell EMC manifests.

The implementation I proposed uses the raw value if a string like '192.168.0.1' or '192.168.0.1,192.168.0.2' is passed while it converts a array value like ['192.168.0.1', '192.168.0.2'] to a string like '192.168.0.1,192.168.0.2'.
So it is still compatible with the existing implementation but accepts more flexible definition by array. 

I see that we don't have this implementation in many other drivers so maybe we can leave it now. However I still think this is a valid improvement and something worth implementing later.

how consistently did the above test_enable_console_already_enabled() fail for you without the above change? Because this test is basically the same as the above one.

Also, what was failing? Both mock_sc & mock_notify were being called?

Thanks for having a look! With the old order (stop_service before the asserts) the test failed 100% for me. With the new order it succeeds 100%.

> Both mock_sc & mock_notify were being called?

Yes.

> Because this test is basically the same as the above one.

I totally agree :) As mentioned, there seems to be another task manager instantiated when stop_service() is called. This task manager has the console not enabled, but it gets enabled when init_host and start_consoles is invoked. And these are the calls to mock_sc and mock_notify we see.

Ah. ok. So in test_enable_console_already_enabled(), the node has console_enabled=True. My guess is that when _stop_service() happens, this [1] is invoked, which causes the console to be enabled -- in a thread. With your change, this [2] is faster and hence the mocked console calls are made before the test does the .assertFalse() stuff.

I'm not quite sure what causes [1] to be invoked but 😊

And it doesn't fail in this test, cuz the console is disabled for this node, so no calls are made to enable it.

    isort_obj = isort.SortImports(
AttributeError: module 'isort' has no attribute 'SortImports'

To fix this, simply add here isort explicitly, e.g.:
isort>=4.2.5,<5.0.0

The more I think about this, the less I like doing this vs introducing new options. The prefixes are far too special flower for my liking. What is the opposition to 'cpu_model_extra_enabled_flags' and 'cpu_model_extra_disabled_flags'? Most of this is managed by tooling so it's not worse for our users, but it's objectively easier for us to reason about.

My objection against two flags: needlessly introducing more config options (even if they're handled by management tooling), the verbosity, more work for higher-level tooling without much benefit, and not to mention the deprecation dance.

I don't think the +/- usage is too special-flowery.  It feels "new", but once you get past that, you can see how it is intuitive, clear, short, and reusing an existing flag in a meaningful way.  You can't misunderstand it even if you try to.

nova/virt/libvirt/config.py.message: Should this be LibvirtConfigGuestCPUFeature also? Below we only add non disable policies, but we could also use LibvirtConfigGuestCPUFeature and store the policy directly.

I don't think so, as LibvirtConfigCPUFeature() is the main base class for defining CPU features.  As a refresher (to myself) the function of four classes are:

- LibvirtConfigCPUFeature - the base class for defining CPU features
- LibvirtConfigCPU - base class for defining CPU models
- LibvirtConfigGuestCPUFeature - extension for setting the guest-specific CPU "feature" policy — here, libvirt allows five possible values: force, require, optional, disable, forbid
- LibvirtConfigGuestCPU - extension for setting the guest-specific "match" policy, and allowing use of host CPU model passthrough — here, libvirt allows three possible values: minimum, exact, and strict
OK, this is more complicated than I originally thought. I trust your judgement here.

I'm going with Artom's nice-to-have suggestion; so locally I went with _prepare_cpu_flag(), which is simliar to "update"; hope that works for you too.


    def _prepare_cpu_flag(self, flag):
        if flag.startswith('-'):
            flag = flag.lstrip('-')
            policy_value = 'disable'
        else:
            flag = flag.lstrip('+')
            policy_value = 'require'

        cpu_feature = vconfig.LibvirtConfigGuestCPUFeature(
                        flag, policy=policy_value)
        return cpu_feature

And then, later in the other two methods, call:

    cpu_feature = self._prepare_cpu_flag(flag)
    cpu.add_feature(cpu_feature)

Being meticulous is a virtue; but as with anything, moderation matters.  I'm all for maintainability, even to the point that I often emphasize it over new features.  And the term "best practices" is loaded, and doesn't mean very much until it is unpacked.

Ok, so this paragraph finally made it clear for me.  A packet arrives at the neutron router, which NATs and forwards it to the backend network.  Instead of using ECMP to decide between which network (or maybe you want to do that to?), it's being used to decide the next-hop destination, which is one of the load-balancers.  Hopefully I'm correct there.

So Octavia is still doing health monitoring and liveness detection, but has to do an additional step of updating the ECMP configuration in Neutron on a failure.  How quickly does this ECMP update need to be to have minimal packet loss?  For example, on a loaded system a router update could take many seconds or longer, is that sufficient?

Yes, it decides the next-hop destination.
It does take serveral seconds from the time a failure occurs to the time the ECMP route is finally updated. Of course we want this time to be as short as possible, but for a typical large physical network, the convergence time for a single point of failure is between 5 and 7 seconds, and I think it's OK as long as the ECMP convergence time is around 5 seconds.

Based on lines 266-274 "This scheme" refers to consistent hashing. Stating this explicitly would help the reader here.

Don't we conflate two things here?

1) What is the input to the (outgoing link selector) hash? 3-tuple or 5-tuple?

2) Is the hashing consistent or not? You use the word "persistent", but I usually find this is called "consistent" or "resilient" hashing. From user perspective this difference means that on addition/deletion to/from the ECMP bundle how much traffic gets disturbed/redistributed (almost all or the least possible).

To my understanding both of these options cause observable differences in the behavior of an ECMP router, therefore I think it would make sense to expose these settings via the API. For example as a new router attribute (thinking out loud):

 "ecmp_options": {
     "hash_input": "5-tuple",
     "consistent_hash": False,
 }

Of course the implementation could first reject a router creation request with consistent_hash=True as unimplemented. But we would have a way to introduce consistent hashing and make it queryable/settable by the user.

Yes, due to the functionality of Octavia, I plan to merge the ECMP implementation I'm currently using first, and then make improvements later.
As for how users will know which version is being used, how about changing the shim extension name from 'ecmp-route' to 'ecmp-iptables'?

What I mean is that adding ECMP routing in the current scheme does not allow for consistent hashing, and we need to pursue consistent hashing to ensure that the network traffic receives minimal impact when a node is unreachable.

I don't think it is necessary to add a new router attribute to allow users to choose whether to use a consistent hash or not, because there is no reason for users not to use a consistent hash when it can be achieved.

I fully agree consistent hashing is desired.

However I'm a bit lost why is this marked as Prio2 then. The note in line 33 says that you intend to merge ecmp support first without consistent hashing. Then later add consistent hashing as a separate feature. How can a user find out which version he's getting?

If we want the API to be generic and work with other future ECMP implementations too (for example with hardware routers where we don't control the implementation, whether they can use a 5-tuple or do consistent hashing) I still believe the explicit extra API option better covers the possibilites.

While I believe this makes sense here in the scope of this spec, I'm open to taking this to a followup spec.

By intranet client you mean a port/IP from the same subnet where the ECMP nexthops are, right?

Why do we keep the client and the nexthops in the same subnet in the first place? Is this mandated by Octavia? If yes, why?

If we had them in different subnets (both connected to the router via router interfaces), then the traffic would naturally flow through the router and the arp-proxy in the implementation patch would become unnecessary.

Using an arp-proxy to force intra-subnet traffic still through the router is quite surprising. Causing the least surprise is generally desirable. Do we have a reason that outweighs the surprise?

I'm not necessarily against convenience features like this arp-proxy. However here too I'm considering hardware-router based implementations where dropping in an extra arp proxy may not be trivial or possible at all. That's why I would suggest at least making the arp-proxy feature into something optional - so another implementation could choose to not implement it.

This is really to accommodate the same subnet case, although there is no use case that requires being on the same subnet, and there is no feature distinction between being on and off the same subnet.
After all, the same customer's hosts are likely to be planned in the same subnet.

Happily, turning on the arp proxy does not affect normal host communication on the same subnet (this is the result of my experiment, probably because these hosts did not turn off arp response) so don't worry too much about 'surprising traffic'.

Sorry, but I still do not agree. We already have an ECMP implementation in OpenDayLight that does not have the proposed ARP proxy, but uses the same API. Also we should not make future hardware-router backends impossible by making the ARP proxy mandatory.

In a production environment, a virtual machine created by a customer is often planned on one subnet, so that the client virtual machine he creates and the servers he needs to use for load balancing are on a subnet.

I understand that people may have previously put various VMs in the same subnet. But I'm asking for something different: What is the use case for having them in the same subnet? In other words: What feature (if any) is lost if we mandate the client and the nexthops being on separate subnets?

The other side is clear: without proxy arp the implementation is simpler and we don't create surprising traffic flows.
Again, I'm not against an optional arp proxy, but we cannot expect a OpenStack client to magically know the server side configuration. If it behaves differently it must look different in the API too.

Generally speaking, the API definition is a combination of REST API request/response AND expected behavior. Ideally all backend behaviors are visible via the API.

On the other hand, the feature discussed here, proxy ARP for ECMP, sounds a gray zone.

I see several implementation-specific differences (including this spec):

- ECMP support itself
- Proxy ARP for ECMP

Regarding the first one, whether ECMP support is enabled is NOT expressed via API, so we already have different behaviors per backend.
The second one, proxy ARP for ECMP, can be considered as a same level as the first one.

Thus, I agree that this kind of difference should be expressed via the API ideally, I am not sure we need to do it for "proxy ARP for ECMP" only.

FYI: If we express the availability of "proxy ARP for ECMP", a backend driver can declare if the feature is supported or not and we can control the API extension based on this information. I don't think a config option is required. (As an implementation reference we can refer to the implementation of the security group extension https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/src/branch/master/neutron/agent/securitygroups_rpc.py#L48)

> Again, I'm not against an optional arp proxy, but we cannot expect a OpenStack client to magically know the server side configuration. If it behaves differently it must look different in the API too.

If it is, then your suggestion (that is implementing lines 273-274) involves a from-scratch implementation of consistent hashing. Which I believe is not a trivial task. That's why I was suggesting to explore a possibly already existing open source implementation (ipvs+maglev).

The Linux kernel routing module does not currently implement ecmp routing for consistent hashing, so it has to make a detour based on hmac to implement consistent hashing.

I googled a bit more and put together a play-environment. It seems to be doing the job properly.

Simulate having 3 backends.
Make sure we can identify which backend a request hits, by serving different content.
 $ mkdir 8001
 $ mkdir 8002
 $ mkdir 8003
 $ echo 8001 > 8001/test
 $ echo 8002 > 8002/test
 $ echo 8003 > 8003/test
 $ ( cd 8001 && python3 -m http.server 8001 & )
 $ ( cd 8002 && python3 -m http.server 8002 & )
 $ ( cd 8003 && python3 -m http.server 8003 & )

See if the "backends" work.
 $ wget -q -O- http://127.0.0.1:8001/test
 ...

Install user space utilities for IPVS.
 $ sudo apt-get install ipvsadm

Add a VIP (here just port 8000 on the loopback interface) with the 3 "backends" we have.
The real work is done in the Linux kernel, the mh (Maglev Hashing) scheduler I believe is available since Linux 4.18.
In a real setup we would probably use "-g / --gatewaying" instead of "-m / --masquerading".
 $ sudo ipvsadm -A -t 127.0.0.1:8000 -s mh
 $ sudo ipvsadm -a -t 127.0.0.1:8000 -r 127.0.0.1:8001 -m
 $ sudo ipvsadm -a -t 127.0.0.1:8000 -r 127.0.0.1:8002 -m
 $ sudo ipvsadm -a -t 127.0.0.1:8000 -r 127.0.0.1:8003 -m

Test a request on the VIP. In my environment this request was scheduled to backend 8002.
 $ wget -q -O- http://127.0.0.1:8000/test
 8002

What happens if I delete a different backend? No disruption, the request is not re-scheduled.
 $ sudo ipvsadm -d -t 127.0.0.1:8000 -r 127.0.0.1:8001
 $ wget -q -O- http://127.0.0.1:8000/test
 8002

Add it back after the disruption test.
 $ sudo ipvsadm -a -t 127.0.0.1:8000 -r 127.0.0.1:8001 -m

What happens if I delete backend 8002? Of course the request must be re-scheduled.
 $ sudo ipvsadm -d -t 127.0.0.1:8000 -r 127.0.0.1:8002
 $ wget -q -O- http://127.0.0.1:8000/test
 8001

But when we add backend 8002 back, the request gets back too.
 $ sudo ipvsadm -a -t 127.0.0.1:8000 -r 127.0.0.1:8002 -m
 $ wget -q -O- http://127.0.0.1:8000/test
 8002

According to "man ipvsadm":

mh - Maglev Hashing: assigns incoming jobs based on Google's Maglev hashing algorithm, providing an almost equal share of jobs to each real server and provides minimal disruption. When the set of real servers  changes, a  connection  will likely be sent to the same real server as it was before.  This scheduler has two flags: mh-fallback, which enables fallback to a different server if the selected server was unavailable, and mh-port, which adds the source port number to the hash computation.

I think we need a shim extension to make this behavior change discoverable. Otherwise an unsuspecting client can do the same thing against two different Neutron versions and get two different behaviors.

> I think we need a shim extension to make this behavior change discoverable. Otherwise an unsuspecting client can do the same thing against two different Neutron versions and get two different behaviors.

What do you mean by "shim extension"? I hope you can give an example of the effect you want to achieve. And how can an openstack environment has two different Neutron versions?

By shim extension I mean adding a new record to the list of supported extensions, so we have something on the API, that can be queried and used to discover which behavior to expect. When there's no change in API syntax, only a semantic (behavior) change we usually still add an extension for that and call it a "shim extension". Here's a patch that does something similar:

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/562320

If you search between neutron reviews for 'shim' you can find a whole lot of these.

Does that make sense?

Regarding the multiple versions: A client (including a human non-admin user of a cloud) generally does not know what version of OpenStack is on the other side and it may talk to multiple OpenStack deployments. When we change a behavior for the same API input, it needs to know which one to expect: the original or the changed behavior.

I think you have seen the old version of this part。
Reviewer Lajos Katona said ：”This part sounds too loadbalancer specific“
So I've modified and simplified this passage into the terminology。

The old version of this part was：

  -  Use `HMARK` in mangle table, marking flows with a number:

  ::

    iptables -t mangle -A PREROUTING -p tcp -d <vip> -j HMARK \
    --hmark-tuple src --hmark-mod <N> --hmark-rnd 0xcafeface --hmark-offset X

    #N is the number of the loadbalancers
    #X is the number of the offset where the ecmp table start

  - Distribute flows to different tables by `fwmark` value:

  ::

    ip route add fwmark <X + 0> table <X + 0> pref 100
    ip route add fwmark <X + 1> table <X + 1> pref 100
    ...
    ip route add fwmark <X + N - 1> table <X + N - 1> pref 100


  - For each table, give it a default <nexthop_ip>:

  ::

    ip route add default via <nexthop_ip1> table <X+0>
    ip route add default via <nexthop_ip2> table <X+1>

    ip route add fwmark <X + 0> table <X + 1> pref 100
Why use this config? The "proxy_arp" option has some side effect?

> My question is why we choose "proxy_arp_pvlan"? why we do not use "proxy_arp"?

Although I would love to answer your question in theory, I really haven't found a reason why the proxy_arp parameter doesn't work.

What I want to do is to allow traffic between hosts on the same subnet to be forced through the router, as you can see from the following parameter description and RFC3069, proxy_arp_pvlan should be designed for this need.
https://sysctl-explorer.net/net/ipv4/proxy_arp_pvlan/
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3069

I also found a example from the web that wanted to use proxy_arp to achieve a similar goal but failed.
https://serverfault.com/questions/212074/is-it-possible-to-use-proxy-arp-back-to-the-same-interface

doc/source/contributor/topics/policy.rst.message:
and if i understand correctly, horizon need deprecated rules to support the old token to keep working? 
But that can be done if you do not pass the policy_file at all? or is it to avoid any break if project started to remove the deprecated rules and Horizon need time to switch to new policy?

> > and if i understand correctly, horizon need deprecated rules to support the old token to keep working? 
> 
> Yes, deprecated rules in keystone and nova policies are required to make horizon work well. Horizon does not support system-scoped token yet and it depends on project/domain-scoped token at the moment.
> 
> Even after horizon supports system-scoped token, I think it is still useful because operators potentially use deprecated rules and have not migrated to new rules.
> 
> > But that can be done if you do not pass the policy_file at all? or is it to avoid any break if project started to remove the deprecated rules and Horizon need time to switch to new policy?
> 
> The reason that horizon load policies from dumped policy files is because it is too much to import service project python codes like nova, keystone and so on. Is there any way to load default policies without importing nova and so on?

Not that I'm aware of. Even if we had an easy way to import the default policies registered in code, we'd likely still need the policy file to support overridden policies.

> and if i understand correctly, horizon need deprecated rules to support the old token to keep working? 

Yes, deprecated rules in keystone and nova policies are required to make horizon work well. Horizon does not support system-scoped token yet and it depends on project/domain-scoped token at the moment.

Even after horizon supports system-scoped token, I think it is still useful because operators potentially use deprecated rules and have not migrated to new rules.

> But that can be done if you do not pass the policy_file at all? or is it to avoid any break if project started to remove the deprecated rules and Horizon need time to switch to new policy?

The reason that horizon load policies from dumped policy files is because it is too much to import service project python codes like nova, keystone and so on. Is there any way to load default policies without importing nova and so on?

> Even if we had an easy way to import the default policies registered in code, we'd likely still need the policy file to support overridden policies.

This implement introduces two types of policy files.
The one is "default rules" specified in DEFAULT_POLICY_FILES. They are mirrors of registered rules in back-end services.
The other is "policy files" specified in POLICY_FILES. They correspond to /etc/<xxxx>/policy.yaml and operators should modify these when overriding registered default rules.

"an easy way to import the default policies registered in code" just helps the first one. Users can define overridden policies with the latter.
or extend the oslo tool too to generate the deprecated rule too?

It can and I am okay with either direction, but I am not sure whether there is such need outside of horizon.
Horizon needs the relationship between deprecated rules and new rules. The current oslo tool outputs deprecated information as comments but I am not sure the proposed format like [1] is useful for others.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/750134/2/openstack_dashboard/conf/default_policies/nova.yaml

++

In addition to these points, Ghanshyam highlighted the importance of switching to YAML in his proposal for a community-wide goal [0].

[0] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/governance/+/759881/3/goals/proposed/migrate-policy-format-from-json-to-yaml.rst
I do not cover all of the backgrounds here. I added a link to the community goal here.

openstack_auth/policy.py.message: To clarify, you're requiring this method to load and register policy rules from the generated sample policy files because we don't have instances of registered defaults from the service, correct?

Yes, this is to get enforcer instances with registered defaults. We cannot import registered rules from services , so instead this method loads registered rules from YAML file. Precisely speaking, sa you may know, YAML files used here have a bit different formats from "generated sample policy files" by oslopolicy-sample-generator.

openstack_dashboard/conf/default_policie.message:
Will these populate automatically when cinder merges support for secure RBAC and scope_types?

https://review.opendev.org/q/owner:self+status:open+project:openstack/cinder+topic:secure-rbac

Yes, we need to sync this file with the cinder repo.
openstack_dashboard/management/commands/dump_default_policies.py generates this file based on the cinder repo.
At the moment, this is a manual process, but it can be done by a periodic job in future.
